entry.title: Securing Agentic AI Through Threat Modeling at SAP
entry.content:
By Helen Oakley, Senior Director of Software and AI Security, SAP Global Security & Cloud Compliance 

This year, at SAP Sapphire, SAP unveiled its expanded vision for Business AI, introducing a growing network of Joule Agents that work across systems and lines of business. This marks a clear step into the era of Agentic AI ‚Äì systems that can understand context, take initiative, and drive outcomes autonomously. ‚ÄúSAP combines the world‚Äôs most powerful suite of business applications with uniquely rich data and the latest AI innovations to create a flywheel of customer value,‚Äù said CEO Christian Klein. While this evolution opens exciting possibilities for automation and productivity, it also introduces a new layer of complexity in how we approach security. Agentic systems challenge traditional safeguards, making it essential to identify and mitigate risks early through tailored threat modeling. 

At its core, threat modeling is about asking the right questions early in the development process, while the system is still being designed and built. Rather than simply looking for bugs or code flaws, it forces us to think through how a system might behave in the real world. What could go wrong if an agent‚Äôs goals are manipulated? Could someone poison its memory over time? What if an agent uses a tool in an unintended or unsafe way? How could agent-generated content be used to mislead or overload human decision-makers? What happens when agents collaborate or collide in ways that expose the system to cascading failures or manipulation? 

These are not hypothetical questions. They reflect the real and emerging risks of agentic systems. The OWASP Agentic AI Threats & Mitigations Guide is a valuable resource that brings structure to this thinking. It highlights specific threats such as memory poisoning, cascading hallucinations, privilege compromise, and agent communication poisoning. For teams building these systems, it helps provide a common vocabulary and practical examples to guide threat modeling work. 

To give an example of how threat modeling helps in practice, let‚Äôs take the case of goal manipulation ‚Äì one of the emerging risks identified in the OWASP guide. In agentic systems, attackers don‚Äôt necessarily need to exploit traditional software flaws. Instead, they can attempt to influence an agent‚Äôs behavior over time by subtly manipulating its objectives. This might happen through indirect prompt injection, compromised data sources, or crafted tool responses. Imagine an agent responsible for prioritizing financial transactions; if adversarial inputs gradually shift its decision logic, it could start approving risky payments outside of the intended policy. In threat modeling exercises, we explore how such scenarios could play out by analyzing how the agent forms and updates its goals, how memory and feedback loops could reinforce undesired behaviors, and how downstream actions might be impacted. This helps define targeted mitigations, such as isolating goal-setting logic from external inputs, monitoring shifts in agent behavior, and adding human validation for sensitive decisions. 

The OWASP Agentic AI Threats & Mitigations Guide provides a helpful reference architecture that illustrates where these types of risks can emerge. The diagram below maps threats to key components in a typical agentic system, making it easier to visualize how threat modeling applies in practice. 

Image Source: OWASP Agentic AI Threats and Mitigations guide, ‚ÄúThreat Model Summary‚Äù 

At SAP, threat modeling has long been part of our Secure Software Development and Operations Lifecycle (Secure SDOL), which is certified under ISO 27001. This framework ensures security is built into every phase of the product lifecycle, from design to operations. With Agentic AI, we are expanding our threat modeling approach to address risks that don‚Äôt typically appear in traditional application security. This includes analyzing agent memory behavior, reasoning patterns, system autonomy, human interaction points, and the dynamics of multi-agent ecosystems. The focus shifts from identifying static vulnerabilities to understanding how autonomy and learning can lead to unintended behaviors. From there, we define appropriate controls and mitigations to reduce those risks. 

The field of Agentic AI security continues to take shape. Standards like ISO 42001 and regulations such as the EU AI Act are in development, and industry best practices are actively maturing. That‚Äôs why collaboration is essential. SAP is contributing to the conversations held with industry groups focused on these challenges, including OWASP GenAI initiatives. We‚Äôre not just adopting ideas, we‚Äôre helping shape them, working with peers and regulators to advance the state of AI security. Our teams bring deep expertise in both enterprise security and AI systems, offering a perspective that‚Äôs helping guide how the broader ecosystem approaches agentic risks. 

Transparency remains central to how SAP approaches product security. As we continue evolving our work with AI, we‚Äôre committed to sharing what we learn through resources like the SAP Trust Center. Security is not a one-time effort. It is a continuous process, especially with systems as dynamic as Agentic AI. 

Threat modeling helps us stay ahead of these evolving risks and supports the design of systems that are both capable and safe. As Agentic AI becomes more embedded in enterprise workflows, this kind of proactive thinking becomes essential. 

SAP is proud to contribute to shaping the future of secure AI. By collaborating across the industry and applying deep expertise from our teams, we‚Äôre helping advance practical, forward-looking approaches to securing the next generation of intelligent systems.

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: AI-Powered Fraud Prevention
entry.content:
As we are all (too much) aware, Artificial Intelligence has changed our working habits. Sometimes for the good, such as creating a nice illustration for this blog, but also sometimes to the benefit of the dark force when used with malicious intents.

In the area of fraud, AI-generated deception strategies have become more and more sophisticated.

While confirming during a Teams meeting with the Treasurer that a request for an urgent transfer was legitimate and was previously a sure protection against business email compromise scams, advanced audio and video deepfakes have rendered this earlier failsafe obsolete.

So, should we just give up and all move to just one office location so that you can get in person confirmations on sensitive transactions?

No, of course not.

In this blog, I‚Äôd like to discuss how SAP solutions for Governance, Risk, and Compliance can be enhanced with ‚Äúlast mile checks‚Äù from Trustpair to catch any fraudulent activity before it‚Äôs too late.

 

Building a resilient treasury governance

 

With ninety percent of US companies reporting being targeted by cyber fraud in 2024, and thirty-eight percent targeted by payment fraud more than 10 times over the same period as per Trustpair‚Äôs Fraud in the Cyber Era: 2025 Fraud Trends & Insights, this is clearly not an isolated issue and it‚Äôs not going away any time soon. And just to put it into perspective, the FBI‚Äôs latest Internet Crime Report mentions that business email compromise alone totalled $2,770,151,146 reported losses in 2024...

To combat this scourge, companies are investing in 3 main areas:

 

Training & Awareness

Authorizations

Technology

Training & Awareness and Authorizations are perfect examples of preventative control measures: by reducing the fraud attack surface, companies reduce the likelihood of a fraud succeeding.

But much like phishing attacks, if the sample is large enough and the incentives sufficiently compelling, chances are that business email compromise scams will still succeed. And when you think that findings from the 2025 AFP¬Æ Payments Fraud and Control Survey indicate that only 22% of organizations were able to recover 75% or more of the funds lost due to payments fraud in 2024, more proactive measures are needed.

This is where technology plays an important role, in my opinion, to address the remaining gap and moves the needle to earlier detection ‚Äì before the loss is incurred.

 

Fraud prevention triangle

 

Indeed, what if the treasury employee targeted already has the role and authorization to perform the transaction, had the relevant training and is aware that these types of attacks exist but has been convinced by an advanced deepfake that the request is legitimate and still processes the payment?

This where technology takes the relay and enhances human checks to provide a last dependable defense layer based on 3 angles creating the Fraud Prevention Triangle. This depiction below is not from me so all credit here goes to my colleague Emanuele Fumeo - Finance Solution Advisor at SAP:

 

 

 

Anomaly detection

By screening large volumes of transactional data, SAP Business Integrity Screening helps identify anomalous activity quickly using flexible rule sets and predictive analyses to uncover potential fraud patterns or deviations from policy.

Should the attack follow a known pattern, it would be detected at this stage.

 

Business Partner Screening

Within SAP Business Integrity Screening, a dedicated module enables enterprises across all industries to screen their business partners against lists of denied persons and organizations published by governments and global institutions, thus ensuring their compliance with guidelines, regulations, and legislation.

If the business party involved in the transaction has already been flagged by authorities as being on a sanctioned list for instance, then this second automated step would prevent any further processing.

 

Account Validation

Finally, even if the attack hasn‚Äôt been detected and the party seems legitimate, Account Validation ‚Äì also known as Confirmation of Payee, is the last mile check. It is the ultimate control and here, TrustPair can automatically perform one-time checks for new vendors in SAP Ariba but also continuous monitoring of vendor master data and payment files in the ERP system to detect risks, abnormal amounts and duplicates. Ultimately making the entire process more secure and efficient with a last protection net validating the company identity, but also the bank account ownership against banking sources.

Together, human factor prevention with adequate training, attack surface reduction with relevant authorizations and advanced technology detection can help ensure that even advanced fraudulent attacks are deterred ‚Äì hence safeguarding the company‚Äôs financials.

And this must be done consistently across the end-to-end procure to pay process but also directly embedded within the transactional systems to ensure adequate and timely action.

What about you, how does your company address the AI-powered fraud threat? I look forward to reading your thoughts and comments on this blog.

And if you are interested in learning more about TrustPair‚Äôs solutions for SAP and how it applies a 5-layer validation with external sources, smart algorithms and complementary checks to secure the source to pay chain, then have a look Trustpair Payment Fraud Prevention on the SAP Store.

entry.title: Navigating Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) in Today‚Äôs Business Environment
entry.content:
In complex regulatory and business environments, organizations are under growing pressure to manage risks, ensure compliance, and uphold strong governance practices. Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) is the strategic framework designed to meet these demands‚Äîhelping businesses align IT with corporate objectives, manage risk proactively, and ensure compliance across an increasingly complex regulatory landscape.

What is GRC?

Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) is a coordinated strategy for managing an organization's overall governance, enterprise risk management, and compliance with regulations. GRC provides a structured approach to decision-making by integrating risk, compliance, and performance data across departments. When effectively implemented, GRC helps reduce uncertainty, control costs, mitigate IT and security risks, and improve overall business performance.

What‚Äôs Driving the Need for GRC Today?

Organizations face big waves in diverse, fast-moving risks‚Äîfrom cybersecurity threats to geopolitical disruptions‚Äîcreating a need for real-time risk awareness and accountability. At the same time, global regulatory frameworks are becoming more demanding and complex, with increasing expectations around transparency and internal controls.

Digital transformation of businesses introduces both opportunity and risk. Real-time processes, machine learning, robotic process automation (RPA), and increased collaboration across organizational boundaries demand new approaches to monitoring, assurance, and control. Traditional, manual GRC practices are no longer sufficient in this dynamic environment.

GRC and SAP‚Äôs Secure Operations Map

In SAP‚Äôs Secure Operations Map (SOM), GRC is embedded in four critical domains:

  • Security Governance
  • Risk Management
  • Regulatory Process Compliance
  • Audit & Fraud Management

This integration provides a foundational structure to ensure GRC principles are applied consistently across IT, finance, and operations.

GRC in the Context of the Secure Operations Map (SOM)

Why Do Organizations Need GRC Tools?

Many organizations still manage internal controls and compliance processes manually‚Äîusing spreadsheets, shared drives, emails, and physical binders. This fragmented approach leads to delays, errors, outdated information, and in some cases, missed control testing. This is especially concerning given the need for CEOs and CFOs to sign off on financial statements under personal liability.

GRC tools centralize and automate these processes, providing:

  • A unified view of internal controls across the enterprise
  • Timely and accurate compliance data
  • Reduced risk of financial misstatements or regulatory breaches
  • Greater efficiency in audits, due diligence, M&A, and IPO processes

The objective is clear: ensure operational consistency, identify irregularities or non-compliance, and build a resilient and trustworthy organization.

Example control - Record-to-Report Process

Implementing a GRC Strategy: Key Steps

1. Define the Purpose and Scope

An effective GRC strategy begins with defining its purpose and scope. Organizations need to determine whether the approach will be applied enterprise-wide or focused on high-risk areas such as finance, IT, or third-party relationships. Objectives such as improving audit readiness, meeting regulatory requirements, and reducing operational risk should be clearly defined from the outset.

2. Establish a Governance Structure

The next step is to establish a governance structure. This involves forming a cross-functional GRC steering committee with representatives from compliance, legal, IT, HR, and business leadership. Responsibility for managing risks, maintaining policies, overseeing controls, and handling reporting must be clearly assigned. A dedicated GRC lead should be appointed to coordinate implementation and ensure consistency across departments.

3. Conduct a Risk and Compliance Assessment

A risk and compliance assessment follows. This assessment identifies internal and external risks, maps relevant regulations such as GDPR, HIPAA, and SOX, and evaluates existing compliance gaps. A risk register is developed to classify risks based on their likelihood and potential impact on the organization.

4. Develop and Document Policies and Controls

With the risks identified, the organization can develop and document appropriate policies and controls. These cover areas such as data protection, access management, and anti-fraud measures. Each risk is linked to corresponding control measures, and responsibilities are assigned using a controls matrix to ensure clear traceability.

5. Select and Deploy a GRC Tool

Selecting and deploying a GRC tool is essential for effective execution. The tool should centralize risk and compliance data, support integration with existing systems such as HR, ERP, and incident reporting platforms, and automate key tasks such as alerts, workflows, and compliance tracking. A pilot rollout helps test the setup in a controlled environment before broader deployment.

6. Train and Communicate

Training and communication play a key role in supporting your GRC framework. Employees receive role-specific training on relevant policies and how to report concerns. Internal awareness efforts help foster a culture of compliance and accountability. Managers are provided with tools such as dashboards to monitor compliance within their teams.

7. Monitor, Audit, and Continuously Improve

To keep the GRC strategy effective, organizations must implement ongoing monitoring, regular audits, and continuous improvement. This involves scheduled control testing, internal audits, and the use of key risk indicators to track changes and emerging issues. Reviewing incidents, near misses, and evolving regulations ensures the GRC framework remains current and effective.

Steps for Implementing a GRC Strategy

Tools for GRC in Hybrid SAP Landscapes: Introducing SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM)

SAP‚Äôs traditional GRC suite‚Äîincluding Process Control (PC) and Risk Management (RM)‚Äîis tightly integrated with on-premise ERP systems. However, in today‚Äôs cloud and hybrid environments, their capabilities can be limited.

Enter SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM): a modern GRC platform designed for hybrid landscapes, including S/4HANA Cloud (both Public and Private Editions). SAP RAM enables organizations to:

  • Leverage a single platform for multiple use cases across the enterprise
  • Turn GRC from a compliance burden into a strategic differentiator
  • Focus resources on high-impact risks, processes, and regulations
  • Continuously monitor control performance using real-time business data
  • Improve compliance and control effectiveness while reducing operational costs

By automating labor-intensive tasks like control testing, RAM not only enhances assurance quality but also frees up internal audit and compliance teams to focus on what matters most.

Example Process Flow in RAM

Final Thoughts

GRC is no longer just a back-office function‚Äîit has become a critical enabler of strategic agility, operational resilience, and trust in the digital age. With a well-defined strategy, clear governance structure, and tools like SAP Risk and Assurance Management, organizations can shift from reactive compliance to proactive risk management and business optimization. As part of this evolution, integrating GRC with security monitoring is essential. Giving responsible teams access to timely and accurate security information strengthens their ability to detect potential threats and respond effectively. Auditing and monitoring tools further enhance this by measuring the success of GRC efforts and highlighting areas for improvement. In the next blog post, we‚Äôll explore how SAP supports real-time security monitoring and auditing‚Äîturning insight into action to improve enterprise security and compliance.

Linda

  • Germany
  • SAP Mentor since 2025
  • Follow Linda on LinkedIn

Linda is an expert in accounting topics. During her career she collected very different experiences. Starting in a big corporation in 2013 she dealt with everyday accounting business which still supports her understanding of the customer perspective and their needs nowadays. 2019 she changed to one of the bigger German consulting companies and took over different roles in several S/4HANA implementation projects. Besides this she became involved to support SAP careers and Women in Tech quite early. Since spring 2024 she changed to a smaller consulting company facing to built up the accounting team and the expertise in this area with an approach of a more customer-centric and sustainable consulting to meet the clients on eye-level and bringing real benefit to them.

Topics of interest: Accounting, Finance, Controlling, Governance, Planning, Financial Supply Chain Management

Linda, what inspired you to become an SAP Mentor?

Colleagues from my network suggested the SAP mentor nomination to me. I frequently use to bring up potential topics to my customers as I am hugely interested in bringing a real benefit to them. For me, the role as a mentor can gather the next stage as I can bring the feedback and user experiences from the customers back to SAP. I believe that this combination improves both the products and the consulting services that all of us provide to our clients.

What advice would like to share with other SAP community members?

I strongly recommend staying in touch with your customers. Listen to them and support them in their activities by bringing up creative ideas and solution approaches. Even if you do not get a deal done today, this strengthens your relationship by building mutual trust. Furthermore, I can give the advice to closely work together with junior consultants within your organization. They are highly motivated and thankful to trustworthy mentors. It is not just about the professional and technical expertise. It is also about the soft factors such as communication, organization, taking care, how to push things forward etc. When all of this comes together, you will build up that kind of consultants that we need for the future.
